body:
Pardon me if this comes off as a noob question cos it is. I wanted to try out both Xamarin a d grpc for the first time in this project. 

Can't the grpc client be in C#? Is the performance hit that much that it just done in C? 
Or is it simply the porting of the code to C# which we aim to avoid here?

Mostly it's about avoiding having to maintain ten different copies of the
same code - especially as we start adding richer functionality.

There are some performance benefits also, but in this case they're really
secondary.

On Sat, Apr 30, 2016, 1:36 PM Froelich Stefan notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Pardon me if this comes off as a noob question cos it is. I wanted to try
> out both Xamarin a d grpc for the first time in this project.
> 
> Can't the grpc client be in C#? Is the performance hit that much that it
> just done in C?
> Or is it simply the porting of the code to C# which we aim to avoid here?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/1620#issuecomment-215993315

That's what I thought. It makes sense.

On Sat, Apr 30, 2016, 8:59 PM Craig Tiller notifications@github.com wrote:

> Mostly it's about avoiding having to maintain ten different copies of the
> same code - especially as we start adding richer functionality.
> 
> There are some performance benefits also, but in this case they're really
> secondary.
>

> wrote:

> > just done in C?
> > Or is it simply the porting of the code to C# which we aim to avoid here?

> > https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/1620#issuecomment-215993315
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/1620#issuecomment-215995145

Second this issue.
IMO, it's vital that grpc be accessible from mobile, including xamarin, and from the browser, on order for it to gain as widespread usefulness as REST.

I _really really_ want to use grpc, but at the moment I'm going to also have to provide a REST api too to enable access from platforms not currently supported.

gRPC currently supports Android Java and ObjectiveC (iOS), so we do have support for mobile.
I agree that Xamarin support would be nice (that's why I filed this issue in the first place), but currently our team is focusing on getting the GA release out of the door. 

If someone from community picks this task up and does some experiments with Xamarin, the help will be very welcome (thus the label "help wanted")

Related question: Is it possible to use GRPC with a Windows Phone App? When I try to install GRPC through NuGet I receive the following error:

> Error     Could not install package 'Grpc.Core 1.0.0'. You are trying to install this package into a project that targets 'WindowsPhoneApp,Version=v8.1', but the package does not contain any assembly references or content files that are compatible with that framework. For more information, contact the package author.            0   

Has anyone had any luck installing GRPC for a windows phone app?

I might be wrong on this, but it might actually already work.
Xamarin recently [announcned](https://blog.xamarin.com/net-standard-library-support-for-xamarin/) .NETStandard support and the pre 1.0.1 grpc core [nuget package](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Grpc.Core/1.0.1-pre1) also supports dot net standard. Not sure on implications though.

@yyannekk, Xamarin's support for .NETStandard definitely helps (we probably don't need to make any changes to the C# code then). But one still needs to have the precompiled native library available for given platform - currently we only have linux, windows and mac support (so it won't work on iOS and Android at least).
If you have time to test the newest Grpc pre package with Xamarin and share your results here, that would be great.
@yyannekk Can you please paste stack traces for any errors you've bumped into?

Ok I now ran into an error that is known and might be solvable, but I just couldn't get it to work.
Here is the [sample project](https://github.com/yyannekk/xamarin-protobuf-sample), that won't compile, because of a missing System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation. 

the Grpc PCL and Proto PCL (both use .NetStandard1.5 and project.json) both compile. The App1 project targets Android Xamarin and uses a packages.config file. When referencing the Grpc PCL, beforementioned error occurs.
This is likely due to [this issue](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/10445). 

I think there are two workarounds avaible. 
1) Converting the main application project to use project.json file to utilize nuget 3. That didn't work. VS complained about a douzen missing files (Android namespace). I'm not sure if I got the conversion right though.
2) Copying the \packages\System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation.4.0.0\ref\netstandard1.1\System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation.dll to the nuget cache and there to \System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation.4.0.0\lib\netstandard1.1\ But didn't work (still missing mentioned dll).

I would appreciate any help or guidance on what to try

@yyannekk  thanks for valuable input. I'd have to experiment a little bit to be able to be able to give some guidance. 

Btw, grpc and protobuf are not the same (protobuf uses the good old PCL profile259 and gRPC targets netstandard1.5 directly). Perhaps you could try to get Protobuf working first - that should really work out of the box, because there is no native dependencies, it's pure C# code. After you have a working example with protobuf, you can try adding gRPC and see what happens.

Btw, the issue you are facing seems not gRPC related at all (perhaps you can isolate that issue and file an issue with xamarin?)

Also, are you trying on Windows with VS2015? If so, you really shouldn't see any nuget 2.x related issues (like https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/10445 you are mentioning), because AFAIK VS uses nuget 3 only.

yes, protobuf works without any issue. For example I [tested](https://github.com/yyannekk/xamarin-protobuf-sample/blob/master/App1/MainActivity.cs) creating and merging a protobuf object and then displaying it in an android xamarin app. The beforementioned problems arise when referencing grpc.

The other stuff I cant comment on at the moment.

FYI I have done some testing in this area and this is what I did (all in VS2015 Update 3):
* Created a netstandard1.5 grpc client 
* Referenced the client, grpc, protobuf and netstandard1.5 from an existing xamarin app
* Commented out code in Grpc.CoreShutdownHooks.Register (this was throwing a NotImplementedException:
`02-12 23:24:26.586: I/MonoDroid(13579): System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. ---> System.NotImplementedException: The method or operation is not implemented.
02-12 23:24:26.586: I/MonoDroid(13579):   at System.Runtime.Loader.AssemblyLoadContext.get_Default () [0x00000] in /Users/builder/data/lanes/3511/501e63ce/source/mono/mcs/class/corlib/System.Runtime.Loader/AssemblyLoadContext.cs:44 
02-12 23:24:26.586: I/MonoDroid(13579):   at Grpc.Core.GrpcEnvironment+ShutdownHooks.Register () [0x00020] in X:\3p\grpc-windows\grpc\src\csharp\Grpc.Core\GrpcEnvironment.cs:356 
`)
* Modified Grpc.Core.Internal.PlatformApis.ctor to hard code isLinux and isMono = true (because RuntimeInformation.FrameworkDescription was throwing an exception: 
`02-12 23:21:21.274: I/MonoDroid(13202): System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. ---> System.TypeInitializationException: The type initializer for 'Grpc.Core.Internal.PlatformApis' threw an exception. ---> System.EntryPointNotFoundException: mono_get_runtime_build_info
02-12 23:21:21.274: I/MonoDroid(13202):   at (wrapper managed-to-native) System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation:mono_get_runtime_build_info ()
02-12 23:21:21.274: I/MonoDroid(13202):   at System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation.get_FrameworkDescription () [0x00000] in /Users/builder/data/lanes/3511/501e63ce/source/mono/mcs/class/System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation/System.Runtime.InteropServices/RuntimeInformation.cs:45

`

After this, it would run to the point of trying to load the native libgrpc_csharp_ext library and fail with the following callstack:
`02-12 23:00:53.409: I/MonoDroid(11920): UNHANDLED EXCEPTION:
02-12 23:00:53.433: I/MonoDroid(11920): System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. ---> System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Error loading native library. Not found in any of the possible locations: /storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so,/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/runtimes/linux/native/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so,/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/../../runtimes/linux/native/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so

02-12 23:00:53.433: I/MonoDroid(11920):   at Grpc.Core.Internal.UnmanagedLibrary..ctor (System.String[] libraryPathAlternatives) [0x00008] in X:\3p\grpc-windows\grpc\src\csharp\Grpc.Core\Internal\UnmanagedLibrary.cs:65

Not found in any of the possible locations: /storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so,/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/runtimes/linux/native/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so,/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.test.app/files/.__override__/../../runtimes/linux/native/libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so

For kicks, I then tried adding the native lib as an AndroidNativeLibrary, but that failed to package with:
`3>Cannot determine abi of native library Assets\libgrpc_csharp_ext.x64.so.`

Not sure where to go next with this, but I am really interested in using grpc in this xamarin app

I've been working on this as well. I did the same thing with the C# side, but the critical bit is cross compiling  the grpc_csharp_ext project targeting Android.
I installed [Visual C++ for Cross Platform Mobile.](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn707591.aspx)
I grabbed this [precompiled openssl library](https://github.com/leenjewel/openssl_for_ios_and_android/releases/tag/20170105)
Completely trashed the vcxproj files so they are in a state consistent with a mobile library build.
Added the Android NDK header files and libraries included in the Visual C++ install, and the openssl headers and library from the precompiled distribution.

I get these two types of errors. (more than one of the struct rsa_st errors, I've included one for reference.)
```
2>C:\Users\ashsnelgrove\workspace\grpc\vsprojects\..\src\core\lib\security\credentials\jwt\jwt_verifier.c(483,10): error : incomplete definition of type 'struct rsa_st'
2>               rsa->n = bignum_from_base64(validate_string_field(key_prop, "n"));
2>               ~~~^
2>         C:\Users\ashsnelgrove\Downloads\openssl_curl_for_ios_android.20170105\output\android\openssl-android-x86\include\openssl/ossl_typ.h(110,16) :  note: forward declaration of 'struct rsa_st'
2>         typedef struct rsa_st RSA;
3>C:\Users\ashsnelgrove\workspace\grpc\vsprojects\..\src\csharp\ext\grpc_csharp_ext.c(34,10): fatal error : 'src/core/lib/support/string.h' file not found
3>         #include "src/core/lib/support/string.h"
3>                  ^
3>         1 error generated.
3>         The command exited with code 1.
3>       Done executing task "ClangCompile" -- FAILED.
3>     1>
3>Done building target "ClCompile" in project "grpc_csharp_ext.vcxproj" -- FAILED.
3>
3>Build FAILED.
```
The struct that jwt_verifier.h is looking for is in rsa.h. If I add ```#include <rsa.h>``` it complains that it can't find it. rsa.h does show up in the External Dependencies list.
src/core/lib/support/string.h is in gpr. I obviously don't have the project completely set up correctly, it isn't referencing the headers correctly.

That's as far as I got on Friday, I will continue to work on this.
Here's the patch, beware that I haven't spent any time making the library paths generic, everything is absolute to my box.
[patch.txt](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/files/771494/patch.txt)

First problem is that I didn't remove the reference to packages.config in the project file and Nuget was pulling in grpc's precompiled zlib and openssl packages (grpc.dependencies.zlib.redist etc). There was some conflicts between this and the openssl library I was using.

Second, it appears that the prebuilt openssl I'm pulling in is not the same version as the grpc redistributable. the header files don't line up. The nuget dependency lists version 1.0.204.1, while the precompiled openssl is version 1.1.0c. I'm going to build openssl 1.0.2 directly.

Update:
Some kind soul already built a nuget package "openssl-android" for version 1.0.2

Thanks for the updates @yashton, not sure I will have time to delve into the native library compilation. Based on what you have done so far, does it feel like a lot of work to get the lib to compile? 

I might try getting something going importing the Java implementation into the Xamarin app.

I've successfully compiled the native library targeting android. I can't find where it uploads my grpc library file, so I just transferred it to the emulator directly. I have been unable to get the dlopen call against libdl.so to work, even when it detects the path as correct.

I tried going back to basics with a direct dll import as described (here in the mono docs)[http://www.mono-project.com/docs/advanced/pinvoke/]
```
        [DllImport("libgrpc_csharp_ext_mobile.so")]
        internal static extern IntPtr grpcsharp_version_string();
```
I can successfully call that and get a IntPtr back.

@lostobject Was in the middle of posting when you replied. It is definitely doable, assuming that calling one function indicates everything will work. The core .NET library uses some delegates to allow dynamic loading of the library in NativeMethods. It should be pretty straightforward to change that to the DllImport annotation, preserving the signatures. I could whip up a quick script to do that change to see if it can be done so that we can verify an actual functioning native library. If someone else has anymore experience with how android stores and loads the native libraries, it might be possible to use dlopen. I'll do some research.
Getting all of this into a repeatable build is a different question :-D I'll try cleaning up my grpc repo and make a fork so others can join in.

A fork would be good :)
Not sure how much I'll be able to add since I am new to Android native, but I will try.

Fork at https://github.com/yashton/grpc/tree/v1.0.x
:-D This is a new toolchain for me too.

@yashton & @lostobject, thanks for sharing your progress here.

Some questions:
- Wouldn't it be easier to build the android native library on Linux rather than with Visual C++ (I'm pretty sure we've already done that in other context)?
- Is there any build instructions in the fork you can point me to?
- Has anyone tried experimenting with Xamarin for iOS or Mac OS X?  (Mac might be useful for experimenting, as compiling grpc_csharp_ext.so for Mac OS X already works no problem).

Btw, the branch 1.1.x has been released recently.

Add [DllImport] vs getting a delegate from a function pointer: until summer 2016, we've actually been using DllImports when on windows, but then we got rid of that code to avoid being repetitive. If things work with [DllImport] (they should), figuring out how to get function pointers working or add DllImports back is mostly a technicality.
I think grpc_csharp_ext should use pure csharp, otherwise the users have to compile it for each CPU architecture.
Hi, any news?
Still seems to be an issue.  I am getting the exact same error.
Hi, any news?

I would really like to see Xamarin support in the near future, or at least a (short) readme/guide to compile the core and grpc_ext for the specific plattforms (iOS, Android).
I didn't find any useful tips on how to other then here and https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/11686
